audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing himself as Kent Hovind, a former high school science teacher. He speaks with a conversational tone. He talks about how tree ring dating, or dendrochronology, is reliable but says carbon dating "doesn't work." A different male speaker interjects with a skeptical tone. He claims carbon dating does indeed work. This speaker continues in a sarcastic tone, stating that carbon dating has been done since 1949. He says that samples of known age were carbon-dated in blind tests and the results were confirmed. He then asserts that if carbon dating didn't work, then it wouldn't be used.

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing his video on carbon dating, then claiming that someone is lying about its efficacy. He cites a specific paper, the title of which he mentions is "radiocarbon dating fictitious results with mollusks shells", and he explains that the paper's purpose is to show carbon dating doesn't work under certain circumstances. He then proceeds to quote the paper. The speaker is calm and uses an assertive tone.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the carbon filtering and dissolution processes in plants and rocks, leading to reduced Carbon-14 content and the potential for false readings in carbon dating. His tone is informative and somewhat academic. There are no discernible musical elements or background sounds in the recording.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing Keith and Anderson who were "among the first to alert biologists to this problem". He claims their paper warns biologists about carbon dating inaccuracies under certain circumstances, adding that someone capitalized on this warning to deceive audiences. An abrupt change to a female speaker claiming that carbon dating indicated "live snails had died 27,000 years before". The first male speaker returns, mentioning how stories of snails and "a 1300-year-old seal" are used in creationist arguments. Then another male speaker notes a seal was "carbon dated at 1300 years old" adding that "it's still not working folks". The initial male speaker describes tracking down a paper about this because the creationist source did not cite it correctly. He notes that the author, like the other scientists, mentions the carbon dating as a "warning that carbon dates are inaccurate in marine organisms" due to "the reservoir effect."

The clip starts with a single, clear male voice discussing limitations of carbon dating, mentioning Antarctic water and its impact on the food chain and, hence, on carbon dating's accuracy. The speaker then states that, to some people, this serves as "proof carbon dating doesn't work." A different male voice interjects with a brief, excited claim that "living penguins date 8000 years old." The original male speaker resumes, noting carbon dating isn't one-size-fits-all, and mentioning relative effectiveness for different carbon sources like plants and marine animals.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the limitations of carbon dating, noting itâ€™s not useful for fossils or determining the earth's age. He explains the half-life of Carbon-14 and the limitations of its use, and how a proponent of creationism does not seem to understand this, before pausing on a quote from the same speaker. The speaker is interrupted by another male speaker, whose voice is more energetic, who comments on a fossil being replaced by minerals. The first speaker returns, questioning how carbon dating can be performed on something that is no longer carbon-based. There is an interjection with a higher pitch from the first speaker. A second male speaker disagrees, mimicking the first speaker and highlighting the fossil lacks carbon. The first speaker concludes by remarking that even the dumbest creationist wouldn't have the fossil tested. Finally, another speaker says the first speaker would be wrong.

A male speaker begins, his tone conversational, by describing a situation where Hugh Miller had dinosaur bones carbon-dated. The speaker states that Miller didn't disclose the bones' origin, because had he done so, they would have been considered too old to date using carbon-dating methods. Another male speaker then interjects with a sarcastic tone, exclaiming "Oy, Miller! We can't carbon date that, you idiot! There is no carbon in it!" The first speaker then questions why the bones were dated to 20,000 years old if there was no carbon present, transitioning to the "Miller's tale as told by Mike Lafferty." Following this, a musical segment plays, sounding like a cartoon theme. The music is lighthearted, featuring what sounds like keyboard and xylophone instruments.

The clip begins with an outdoor ambient soundscape. This gives way to a male speaker discussing a person tracing a dinosaur sample at a museum. The speaker is informative in tone, relaying how the subject didn't disclose his intentions for carbon dating. The speaker humorously quotes, "there's no fucking carbon in it", then details how the person "didn't come clean" and again there's the outdoor ambient background.

The clip begins with a male narrator describing how James King, the director of the Carnegie Museum, warned Miller about a bone specimen covered in shellac. He explains that shellac is full of carbon, and this should have alerted a real chemist preparing to carbon date the sample, but it didn't alert Miller. He continues, stating that Miller sent his samples to the University of Arizona, and then a second alarm bell was sounded.

The clip starts with a male speaker, in a lecturing tone, relaying information about an exchange between "Professor of Geochemistry" Long and Miller, involving collagen, carbon, and shellac. He conveys Long's statement that "there is a lot of carbon in the shellac." Another male speaker, in a frustrated tone, says "Look, Miller, do you need this spelled out? If you carbondate this sample, you won't get a date for the fossil, because there's no fucking carbon in it!" He concludes that one would only "get a date for the preservative, and that's exactly what he got." A whimsical, low-pitched tune plays throughout, with what sounds like a tuba or bassoon carrying the melody.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing carbon dating and mentioning a video nominated for a "Golden Crocodile" award. A second male speaker, adopting a casual, conversational tone, introduces himself as "Big Jerry," preparing for another round of answering evolutionist and atheist questions. Transitioning back to the first speaker, who takes on a more critical tone, suggests that Big Jerry's video resembles a sitcom pilot for MBC, remarking that he appears to be someone who doesn't actually have any answers, and seems to place him in the clip for comic relief. The first male speaker then pauses, and briefly confirms his humorous intention. The clip ends with an unidentified speaker saying "Number nine."

A male speaker begins, posing a question about carbon and radiometric dating and their implications for the age of the Earth. He transitions to a conversational tone, remarking on needing to do some research on the topic and then expresses distrust for the dating methods. The speaker then mentions finding an article on the subject.

The clip starts with a male speaker, assertive and somewhat critical, discussing how researchers may "invent excuses" when radiometric dating results differ from expectations, implying "serious problems" with the method. A different male speaker then counters this argument in a more measured tone, questioning the extent of the first speaker's research. The second speaker speculates that the first speaker merely typed "radiometric dating" into a specific Christian website and read what was on the screen "without necessarily understanding it," challenging him with "am I right?" The first male speaker then resumes, continuing to provide examples and critiques of the process of Radiometric dating and giving a specific example regarding fossils.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker concluding a segment, saying "That's all the time I have" and mentioning "answering an evolutionist". He then encourages listeners to return for a part three, stating "Be back soon" in a hopeful tone. Following the speaker, an abrupt, somewhat humorous sound effect plays, potentially indicating the end of the segment in a lighthearted way.
